Title: How can we show that the dyadic rationals are dense in $\mathbb R$?
Content: Numbers of the form $ \dfrac{m}{2^{n}} $, where $ m $ is an integer and $ n $ is a non-negative integer, are called dyadic rational numbers . How can one show that the dyadic rationals are dense in $ \mathbb{R} $?
AcceptedAnswer: So, basically, we have to show that the set of dyadic rationals are dense in $\mathbb{R}$ . For this, if we show that the set $\left\lbrace \frac{m}{2^n}:m\in \mathbb{N}\cup\lbrace 0 \rbrace,n\in\mathbb{N}\text{ and }0\leq m \leq 2^n \right\rbrace$ is dense in $[0,1]$ , then we are done. From this, one can easily extend $\textit{denseness}$ of the above numbers from $[0,1]$ into whole $\mathbb{R}$ . For the above purpose, let $\epsilon >0$ , and let $x\in[0,1]$ . From the Archimedean property, there is $n\in\mathbb{N}$ such that $\frac{1}{2^n}<\epsilon$ . Let $m=\lfloor x\cdot2^n \rfloor$ where $\lfloor\cdot\rfloor$ represents Floor function. Then it is clear that $0\leq m \leq 2^n$ . From the usual properties of Floor function, we have $$m=\lfloor x\cdot2^n \rfloor \leq x\cdot2^n \leq m+1=\lfloor x\cdot2^n \rfloor+1 $$ , i.e., $$ \frac{m}{2^n}\leq x\leq \frac{m+1}{2^n} $$ , i.e., $$ 0\leq x-\frac{m}{2^n}\leq \frac{1}{2^n} <\epsilon $$ which is exactly the statement we want to prove. Thus the set $\left\lbrace \frac{m}{2^n}:m\in \mathbb{N}\cup\lbrace 0 \rbrace,n\in\mathbb{N}\text{ and }0\leq m \leq 2^n \right\rbrace$ is dense in $[0,1]$ . Now just extend this to whole $\mathbb{R}$ .
